description.narrative: Core support to IDLO which works with the promotion of rule of law. This is done through reform and capacity building of rule of law institutions and actors; access to justice for all which also includs work on tradtiional justice and civil society; economic and sustainable justice inluding environment and climate. IDLO also conducts normative work.

Insatsen syftar till att bidra till följande globala resultat:
- Att stärka förtroendet för rättsstatens institutioner och rättsliga reformer - Att stärka tillgången till rättvisa för kvinnor, fattiga och marginaliserade grupper - Att bidra till innovationer inom rättssektorn för att bidra till hållbar utveckling - Att stärka IDLO’s kapacitet som organisation så att de blir en global strategisk partner för att stärka rättsstatens principer.
IDLO är en mellanstatlig organisation som i dagsläget har 26 stater som medlemmar. De samarbetar med stater, civila samhället, FN:s organisationer och program och är skickliga på att skräddarsy och ta hänsyn till lokala förutsättningar vid genomförande av projekt på nationell nivå. IDLO har i dagsläget verksamhet i över 30 länder. IDLO har särskild erfarenhet av att arbeta i fragila stater och har sina största program i Afghanistan, Sydsudan, Kenya och Somalia. IDLO ser just nu över sin programverksamhet och det geografiska engagemanget. Utöver verksamheten på landnivå så är IDLO aktiva i internationella fora och har en viktig röst i utvecklingen av arbetet med rättsstatens principer. Utöver att arbeta med traditionella aktörer inom rättssektorn har IDLO börjat utveckla arbetet med rättsstatens principer inom både hälsa, miljö/klimat och hantering av naturresurser. IDLO har även ökat sitt intresse för att arbeta med gender och har visat på intressanta resultat i t ex Afghanistan där de arbetat mot våld mot kvinnor. IDLO bedöms ha en stark potential att kunna bli en strategisk partner för Sverige inom området för rättsstatens principer.

description.narrative:
The annual report 2018 is the first report in relation to the new strategic plan 2017-2020. 32 % of funds were devoted to impact goal 1 "people and groups are empowered to realise their rights", 60% to impact goal 2 "laws and policies are fair and institutions are effective, accessible and accountable" and 8% to cross-cutting goal rule of law drives sustainable development at local and global levels". Asia was by far the largest region with 54%, followed by Africa with 31%, Europe and Central Asia 6%, Latin America and Caribbean 5 %, Middle East and North Africa and Global with 2 % respectively. A few examples of activities and results for each of the two impact goals are presented below: 1) people and groups are empowered to realise their rights In 2017, IDLO worked to strengthen civil society organizations, and empower women and girls, and poor andmarginalized communities to access justice and claim their rights. IDLO further supported multi-stakeholder processes and inclusive approaches to create laws and policies, empowering civil society to participate in policymaking and strengthening the capacity of communities to access justice. IDLO’s engagement with informal justice systems increased as it explored new ways to close the justice gap at the community level. In addition, IDLO contributed to strengthening women in the judicial profession. In Burundi IDLO have implemented activities focusing on building the capacity of women, while conducting outreach amongcommunities and leaders about the benefits of protecting women’s land rights.IDLO returned in 2017 to engage with women and other community members and found that better recording ofwomen’s customary land rights had, indeed, made a difference. Many of the women reported a feeling of increased empowerment to protect their household land. They spoke about how disputes with male family members over theircustomary right to land had subsided, or even been avoided entirely.Furthermore, surveys showed marked progress in the protection of women’s land rights, whether through registrationof the right in the woman’s own name or, more frequently, through recognition in the form of a derived right. Also, whilethere had been almost no registration of joint ownership between men and women before this project, jointownership was later seen in almost half of land registration cases in surveyed areas. In Myanmar, IDLO contributed to the establishment of four rule-of-law centers as a platform for dialogue and access to resources to address local needs. These centers have trained 1900 civil society organisations, lawyers and others in issues as land rights, legal ethics and sexual and gender based violence. Through mobile training activities, the Centres have reached out to over 7,000 community, religious and youth leaders by the end of 2017, while also engaging with officials. In addition to training, the centres provide a platform for dialogue, allowing community members to interact in new ways.They have generated creative ways of educating people about their rights and enhancing their ability to access justice.One example has been community theater to raise awareness of topics such as domestic violence, drug useand children’s rights.
2) laws and policies are fair and institutions are effective, accessible and accountable In 2017, IDLO developed tailored responses to improve judicial and legal capacity and strengthen the independence and integrity of institutions. Much of its work was carried out in fragile, conflict affected contexts, and contributed to stabilizing and sustaining peace. In line with its Gender Strategy, IDLO gave particular attention to improving institutionalresponses to address SGBV. Building on its previous work, in 2017 IDLO supported the Kenyan judiciary in implementing the Sustaining Judiciary Transformation programme 2016–2021. It focuses on enhancing service delivery by completing and consolidating previous reforms, improving the speed and quality of services, increasing efficiency and effectiveness at individual and system levels, and strengthening individual accountability for performance. Ahead of the country’s elections in2017, IDLO supported state institutions, including the judiciary, on policy, legal and institutional reforms relating to elections and electoral dispute resolution in Kenya. Activities sought to strengthen the capacity of the relevant mechanismsfor efficient electoral dispute resolution, in turn enhancing the credibility of these institutions as effective arbiters of disputes, ensuring public confidence in the judicial process and reducing the risk of political violence. In the2017 general elections, a total of 388 cases were brought to the courts and all judgments were rendered within the statutory deadline of six months. In Liberia IDLO has continued its support to enhance the efficiency, transparency and accountability of the special court to deal exclusively with sexual offenses and improving access to justice and protection mechanisms for survivors of SGBV. IDLO also supported a professional advancement program for female police officers. In addition, IDLO has partnered with a number of civil society organizations that provide support to survivors of SGBV, supporting routine data gathering and progression of each SGBV case from One-Stop Centers to the police, prosecutors and courts. The results in 2017, compared to a baseline report from 2015, showed that the efficiency of the courthad improved and the number of complaints going to prosecution hadincreased. There was a threefold increase in the number of pre-trial detainees that made their first appearance in court within a one year timeframe while 60 % of cases reported to the One-Stop Centers made it into the justice system,reflecting a 45 per cent increase compared to 2015. Whether in fragile contexts, emerging democracies or middle-income countries, IDLO contributed to the 2030 Agenda in 2017 through its programs, research and policy advocacy, positioning the rule of law as a key ingredient for sustaining peace and sustainable development. Building institutions for peace and justice, strengthening accountability, empowering women and girls, fighting corruption, protecting biodiversity and promoting inclusive economic growth are some of the ways in which IDLO’s programs and other activities furthered the implementation of the SDGs in 2017.Engaging in policy dialogue with governments, donors and policy thinkers at global and national levels in 2017, IDLO highlighted the significance of the rule of law for the achievement of Agenda 2030. Throughout 2017, IDLO activelycontributed to debates and discussions at the national and international levels on Agenda 2030, focusing specifically on equality, inclusion and access to rights and justice. For example, IDLO participated in the 2017 UN High-Level PoliticalForum on “Leveraging interlinkages for effective implementation of SDGs”, and contributed to the Global Alliance More than one third of IDLO’s projects included rights of women and girls as a principal or significant objective and all projects were required to undergo a gender analysis at the design stage. In 2017 the strongest gender programming area was the elimination of sexual and gender-based violence, with other areas such as the economic empowerment of women beginning to emerge.
